8814523_syn_2: Procedure Note: A diagnostic and therapeutic pleuroscopy was performed for a recurrent right pleural effusion. Inspection revealed extensive nodular implants consistent with metastatic disease. Multiple parietal and visceral pleural biopsies were obtained. Talc poudrage was performed for pleurodesis, followed by chest tube placement.
8814523_syn_3: Coding: 32650 (Thoracoscopy with pleurodesis). This code includes the diagnostic inspection (32601) and the administration of the pleurodesis agent. Biopsy is technically part of the diagnostic look if not separate code, but 32650 is the primary therapeutic code here.

**PATIENT INFORMATION:**
- Name: Robert Chen

**INSTITUTION:[REDACTED]

**ATTENDING PHYSICIAN:** Dr. Sarah Johnson, MD (Interventional Pulmonology)

**INDICATION:**
73-year-old male with metastatic lung adenocarcinoma and symptomatic recurrent left malignant pleural effusion. Patient has had 4 thoracenteses in past 6 weeks. KPS 60%, prefers home-based management.

**PRE-PROCEDURE:**
- Informed consent obtained, risks discussed including infection (5%), catheter malfunction, pneumothorax, bleeding
- Timeout completed
- Ultrasound: Large left pleural effusion, maximum depth 11.2 cm, free-flowing, no evidence of loculation
- Recent CT chest reviewed: no evidence of trapped lung
- Coagulation panel normal (INR 1.1, Platelets 245K)
- Vital signs: BP 132/78, HR 88, SpO2 90% on 3L NC

**PROCEDURE DETAILS:**
- Patient positioned in right lateral decubitus position
- Left lateral chest, 5th intercostal space, anterior axillary line
- Site id[REDACTED] and marked with ultrasound
- Chlorhexidine prep, full sterile technique with surgical drapes
- Local anesthesia: 25 mL 1% lidocaine (including tunnel tract)
- Small incision made
- Subcutaneous tunnel created to anterior chest wall (8 cm tunnel)
- Sequential dilation of tract
- 15.5 French PleurX catheter inserted under ultrasound and fluoroscopic guidance
- Catheter position confirmed with fluoroscopy
- Valved tip coiled in pleural space
- Sutures placed, cuff positioned in tunnel
- Connected to drainage system
- Initial drainage: 1,350 mL straw-colored fluid removed
- No evidence of re-expansion pulmonary edema
- Catheter functioning well

**CATHETER SPECIFICATIONS:**
- Type: PleurX drainage catheter
- French Size: 15.5 Fr
- Tunnel length: 8 cm

**SPECIMENS SENT:**
- Pleural fluid cytology (previous cytology already positive for adenocarcinoma)

**POST-PROCEDURE:**
- Procedure tolerated well
- Chest X-ray: Catheter in appropriate position, small residual effusion, no pneumothorax
- Patient and spouse trained on drainage procedure by IP nursing staff
- Drainage supplies and vacuum bottles provided
- Written and video instructions given
- Home health agency contacted
- Vital signs: BP 128/76, HR 84, SpO2 94% on 2L NC
- Patient reports improved breathing

**COMPLICATIONS:** None

**ASSESSMENT:** Successful placement of left-sided indwelling pleural catheter for management of recurrent malignant pleural effusion secondary to metastatic lung adenocarcinoma.

**PLAN:**
- Drain every other day initially, adjust frequency based on symptoms and output
- Home health nursing coordination for catheter management
- Weekly catheter site checks
- Patient to call for fever >100.4Â°F, increasing drainage, catheter malfunction, or worsening dyspnea
- Follow-up appointment in 3 weeks
- Continue outpatient chemotherapy as scheduled
- Monitor for spontaneous pleurodesis
